stem: Dr. {{candidate_name}}, you are the anaesthetist on call for obstetrics. A 28-year-old woman has just delivered her baby normally but is now bleeding heavily. The obstetrician estimates 1500 mL blood loss and it continues. How would you manage this?

prompts.text: What are the common causes of postpartum haemorrhage and how would you identify them?
expectedKeyFacts: 4 Ts: Tone (uterine atony), Trauma (genital tract tears), Tissue (retained placenta), Thrombin (coagulopathy)
Uterine atony most common (~70%)
Feel abdomen — uterus should be firm and contracted
Vaginal examination — assess for tears, retained products
Coagulation screen if bleeding not controlled
History: previous PPH, anticoagulants, bleeding disorders
Call for help — activate major haemorrhage protocol
ABC approach: high-flow oxygen, secure large-bore IV access (×2)
Aggressive fluid resuscitation — warm crystalloid and blood products
Activate major haemorrhage protocol — request emergency O-negative blood
Tranexamic acid 1 g IV within 3 hours of delivery
Keep patient warm — prevent hypothermia
Bimanual uterine compression if atony
Monitor: continuous HR, BP, SpO₂, consider arterial line

prompts.text: What pharmacological agents would you use to control uterine atony?
expectedKeyFacts: Oxytocin 5 IU slow IV bolus, then infusion (40 IU in 500 mL over 4 hours)
Ergometrine 500 mcg IM or slow IV (contraindicated in hypertension, pre-eclampsia)
Carboprost (Hemabate) 250 mcg IM, repeat every 15 min up to 8 doses (contraindicated in asthma)
Misoprostol 800-1000 mcg PR
Consider all agents in combination if bleeding not controlled
Monitor for side effects: tachycardia, hypertension, bronchospasm

prompts.text: If medical management fails, what are the surgical options?
expectedKeyFacts: Intrauterine balloon tamponade (Bakri balloon)
Uterine compression sutures (B-Lynch, Hayman)
Systematic arterial ligation (uterine, internal iliac arteries)
Interventional radiology — uterine artery embolisation if haemodynamically stable
Hysterectomy — last resort, life-saving
Involve senior obstetrician and interventional radiology early
Document blood loss, fluids, transfusion in notes
Consider transfer to ICU

rescuePrompt: Perhaps you could tell me about the major haemorrhage protocol — what blood products would you give and in what ratio?
keyFacts: Call for help, activate major haemorrhage protocol
ABC: oxygen, large-bore access, fluid resuscitation
Intrauterine balloon, compression sutures, arterial ligation, hysterectomy
Keep warm, monitor closely, ICU if needed
Blood products: red cells, FFP, platelets in ratio (typically 1:1:1)

scoringGuidance.pass: Systematically applies 4 Ts framework, describes immediate resuscitation including major haemorrhage protocol, knows uterotonic agents with doses and contraindications, aware of tranexamic acid, escalates to surgical options appropriately; stronger candidates discuss transfusion ratios and cell salvage considerations
scoringGuidance.borderline: Mentions some causes and uterotonics but doses unclear, vague on major haemorrhage protocol, mentions surgery but options unclear
scoringGuidance.fail: Does not have systematic approach, unaware of 4 Ts, incorrect drug doses or missing key agents like tranexamic acid, no escalation plan
